text: senator Rubio how far is the US Congress
prepared to go to punish Russia over its
actions in Ukraine well I think there's
a strong bipartisan consensus that the
new international norm cannot be that a
country can simply invade its name bur
lie about it and do so without
repercussions so certainly our ability
to influence the outcome of this is
going to determine our ability to rally
our allies in Europe to take collective
action with regard to this but I think
the commitment is quite strong I think
there's a strong recognition across
party lines that this is an important
moment in the 21st century right but in
terms of the European response there is
clearly reluctance to impose sanctions
they get so much of their gas from
Russia what would your message today be
to America's European allies to say you
have to get on board with this well a
couple things that I would say the first
is we cannot accept as an established
norm in the 21st century that a country
can simply evade invade its neighbours
because they don't like some political
development going on within that country
and I think the repercussions of that
would be felt well beyond Europe I think
there's asia-pacific ramifications to
that as well but I think certainly in
Europe is the first line of this with
regards to the situation that's going on
there I would also say that allowing
this to stand would reward Russia to
undertake this sort of activity in other
parts of Europe in the future which
further destabilizing the region so I do
think it is critical for us and our
allies to act together there must be
consequences for this having happened
we're looking at a situation in Crimea
now where effectively Russia has changed
the facts on the ground already and the
international community has accepted
that it has taken over well our we have
a couple of concerns first we want to
make sure this issue doesn't get any
worse which of course means any
expansion into the eastern part of
Ukraine or even trying to destabilize
the new government in Kiev as it
transitions over to normalcy so we must
do everything we can collectively to
prevent that from happening the second
aspect of it is that there must be a
strong economic and international
diplomatic consequence for the action
that's already taken place and I would
not say the international community has
accepted the situation on the ground I
think we realize what is happening and
has happened but in terms of accepting
that as the new norm I'm not quite sure
that's where the international community
is I think there is collective outre
throughout the world because this has
happened and I think the only debate now
is what do we do about it senator Rubio
you have in the past been a proponent of
American leadership in the world are we
now though looking at a reality a new
world order perhaps in which American
options are very limited and America's
ability to fix crises is effectively
over in this one well I would say to you
that American ability to influence the
world at every stage in America's story
has always been limited I mean it's
never been absolute I think that's a
myth the reality of it is the US economy
is about a 16 trillion dollar economy
the Russian economy is a two trillion
dollar economy in terms of economic
influence Russia and the US are not
peers in that regard what Russia has is
it has significant military capabilities
on a conventional basis and they have
very significant world-class
capabilities on a nuclear front and that
does give them some leverage in terms of
to undertaking actions such as this but
I think that the bigger problem has been
that the notion by this administration
has been that put more responsibility on
our allies around the world to solve
problems while we focus on issues at
home and I think our allies would be the
first to say that sort of approach has
not worked out well Senator Marco Rubio
thank you very much for joining me thank
you
